page.title: 07Farm Interview Part 2
page.content: Some other things Mr Trott told us: Rabbits eat and destroy their crops. They are controlled by organised shoots and a rodent operator controls rats.They have about 4 acres of rough woodland. Most of the fields are steeply sloping to the south. Mr. Trott says that the steepness of the land and the distance covered would make the use of horses uneconomic. Cattle have annual bloodtests for T.B.,brucellosis and treatment against warble-fly. Manure is used for fertiliser but must not be spread in wet weather since run-off pollutes streams.He thinks housing estates should have playing-space as children leave gates open and dogs worry cattle. Rubbish and glass dumped are a danger to cattle and to tractor-tyres which are expensive to replace. No sheep or pigs are kept.
